findings.label: Paid During Active Breaches
findings.detail: 1 suppliers received payments while in breach of Companies Act — including 0 critical and 1 high severity. Temporally verified against payment dates.

findings.label: Likely Duplicate Payments
findings.detail: 334 high-confidence duplicate groups with same supplier, amount, date and reference (3+ copies) (after filtering 821 CSV republication artifacts)
findings.context_note: Quarterly CSV overlaps (same transaction appearing in 2 files) have been filtered out. Remaining duplicates show 3+ identical copies, which are more likely genuine overpayments.

findings.label: Suspected Split Payments
findings.detail: 6 instances of 3+ payments just below approval thresholds in the same week
findings.context_note: Split payment detection has a high false-positive rate. Batch processing, staged invoices, and legitimate recurring payments can all trigger this pattern. FOI request for procurement approval chain recommended before drawing conclusions.

findings.label: Round-Number Payments (>£5K)
findings.detail: 414 exact round-number payments over £5,000 — may indicate estimates rather than invoiced amounts

findings.label: Year-End Spending Pattern
findings.detail: Regeneration & Housing spent 12.9x their monthly average in March (£3.7M above normal). Note: UK councils operate on April–March fiscal years, so elevated March spending is common as departments finalise annual budgets. Spikes above 3x warrant further scrutiny.
findings.context_note: March spending above the monthly average is expected for UK councils on April–March fiscal years. Compare against prior years' March figures for meaningful analysis.

findings.label: Benford's Law Analysis
findings.detail: Digit distribution across 25,507 transactions shows χ²=429.42 (statistically significant due to large sample size), but max digit deviation is only 3.9% — within the normal range for UK council spending patterns. No practical evidence of fabricated invoices.
findings.context_note: Chi-squared values on samples of 25,507+ transactions are naturally inflated and will almost always show statistical significance. The max digit deviation (3.9%) is a more meaningful indicator — deviations under 5% are typical for legitimate council spending.

key_findings.title: Aj Developments (Nw) Ltd: £39.8K paid during active breach
key_findings.description: Company facing strike-off; Confirmation statement overdue

key_findings.title: HM LAND REGISTRY: 2422 transactions totalling £12.0K
key_findings.description: Averaging £5 per transaction — the council's most frequent supplier

key_findings.title: 31 suppliers shared with neighbouring councils — £8.2M total
key_findings.description: Compare what each council pays the same suppliers for similar services

key_findings.title: GO PLANT FLEET SERVICES LTD: 5672% price gap between councils
key_findings.description: Hyndburn pays £59.9K avg vs Pendle £1.0K (both with 3+ transactions). Compared using 2 common financial years. Price differences may reflect different service scope, contract terms, or volumes rather than overcharging — manual review recommended.
key_findings.context_note: Cross-council price comparisons use common financial years only (where both councils have data for the same supplier). This prevents unfair comparisons between councils with different data periods. Differences may still reflect different service levels or contract terms.
